- One-page background handouts: Puritanism/Salem witch trials; McCarthyism/Red Scare.
- Excerpt: Arthur Miller, “Why I Wrote The Crucible” (short version).
- Seminar prep sheet (claim, 3 quotes, 3 questions, connection to today).
- Character map/evidence log handout.
- Logical fallacies mini-sheet (ad hominem, false dilemma, slippery slope, appeal to fear).
- Optional: link to an approved audiobook for homework support.

Week 1

Day 1: Launch and context, start Act I
- Do Now: Quickwrite—Describe a time rumor changed how people acted. Why?
- Mini-lesson: Salem + McCarthyism (timeline; “fear + power + reputation = hysteria”).
- Read Act I opening in class (model annotation for motives and fear language).
- Start character/evidence log.
- Exit ticket: One claim about how fear operates in Act I + one quote.
- Homework: Finish Act I (or to midpoint) and add two entries to evidence log.

Day 2: Act I close reading—power and accusation
- Do Now: 3-sentence summary of Act I so far.
- Mini-lesson: The language of accusation; ethos/pathos/logos in Act I speeches.
- Small groups: Track who gains/loses power scene by scene; pull two quotes.
- Share-out; clarify plot.
- Exit ticket: Identify one persuasive move used by a character; label it.
- Homework: Finish Act I; 5-bullet plot outline.

Day 3: Fallacies and hysteria, finish Act I
- Do Now: One moment in Act I that felt unfair—why?
- Mini-lesson: Common logical fallacies; quick ID in Act I lines.
- Stations or pairs: Find 3 examples of fallacies; explain effect on the court/community.
- Quick read-aloud to finish Act I (if needed).
- Exit ticket: Fallacy + quote + 1-sentence impact on justice.
- Homework: Read Act II, pages 1–10 (or first half). Note one symbol.

Day 4: Act II—reputation vs. integrity
- Do Now: Symbol or motif you noticed; why it matters.
- Mini-lesson: ICE paragraph (Introduce, Cite, Explain) using Proctor-Elizabeth scene.
- Partner work: Draft 1 ICE paragraph on how reputation shapes choices in Act II.
- Share a strong example; collect for quick stamp grade.
- Exit ticket: Self-check—underline the “Explain” sentence in your ICE and label it.
- Homework: Finish Act II; add two quotes to evidence log.

Day 5: Act II wrap + courtroom setup
- Do Now: Write 2 questions you have about the warrants/arrests.
- Roleplay: Short reading of key Act II confrontation; focus on subtext.
- Debrief: What counts as “evidence” so far?
- Preview Act III: the court and “spectral evidence.”
- Exit ticket: Define spectral evidence in your own words + why it’s dangerous.
- Homework: Read first half of Act III; 5-bullet summary.

Week 2

Day 6: Act III—courts, pressure, and power
- Do Now: One tactic Danforth or Hathorne uses to control the narrative.
- Mini-lesson: Rhetorical questioning and burden of proof.
- Close reading: Mary Warren’s reversal; track pressure points.
- Introduce Socratic Seminar: date, topics, prep sheet distributed.
- Exit ticket: Draft a tentative claim for seminar with one quote.
- Homework: Finish Act III; add two questions for seminar prep.

Day 7: Finish Act III, build seminar claims
- Do Now: Choose the single most pivotal moment in Act III—justify.
- Small-group clinic: Turn tentative claims into arguable theses; swap evidence.
- Whole-class: Build a “bank” of high-utility quotes on the board.
- Exit ticket: Finalize your seminar claim (1–2 sentences) + 2 quotes.
- Homework: Read Act IV; complete character/evidence log for one character arc.

Day 8: Act IV + Miller’s purpose
- Do Now: What does Proctor’s choice mean for integrity vs. survival?
- Read key Act IV passages; discuss ending and title significance.
- Short text: “Why I Wrote The Crucible” excerpt; connect to McCarthyism and today.
- Seminar logistics: norms, speaking stems, inner/outer circle plan, score sheets.
- Exit ticket: Write 1 connection between Miller’s essay and a moment in Act III/IV.
- Homework: Complete seminar prep sheet (claim, 3 quotes, 3 questions, modern connection).

Day 9: Seminar prep workshop
- Do Now: Share your strongest quote; partner gives a counterpoint.
- Quick mini: Layering evidence and paraphrasing vs. quoting.
- Fishbowl practice: 8–10 minutes on a warm-up question; feedback on depth and citing.
- Finalize prep; submit prep sheet for credit.
- Exit ticket: Personal goal for tomorrow’s seminar + one talk stem you will use.
- Homework: Review notes; bring annotated text.

Day 10: Socratic seminar + reflection
- Socratic Seminar (30–35 min). Sample anchor question:
  - In The Crucible, is the central conflict individual integrity versus communal survival, or is it power maintenance versus justice? Defend with evidence across Acts II–IV and Miller’s essay.
  - Backup/feeder questions: What counts as truth? How does fear become policy? Where do we see modern analogues?
- Quick debrief: What moved your thinking?
- Exit ticket (post-seminar): 5–7 sentence reflection—How did your view shift? Cite one peer idea and one textual moment.
- Optional summative writing (homework or next class): One polished paragraph extending your seminar claim using two quotes, or a brief compare/contrast to a modern case of moral panic.

Socratic seminar structure (fast and clear)
- Format: Inner/outer circle (half class talks while the other half tracks evidence and questions; then swap).
- Norms: Bring text, speak once before speaking twice, cite specifically (act/scene or brief description), listen to build.
- Stems: “Building on X, …” “A tension I see is …” “The word/line that turns this moment is …” “A counterexample is …”
- Prep sheet requirements (graded for completion): Claim/thesis, 3+ textual quotes with why they matter, 3 original questions, one modern connection.

Daily exit ticket rubric (fast grade, 0–3)
- 3 = Accurate, includes relevant textual support (direct quote or precise reference), and explains significance clearly.
- 2 = Mostly accurate, some evidence or explanation (one is thin or missing).
- 1 = Partially correct or vague, no evidence, unclear reasoning.
- 0 = Not submitted or off-topic.
Tip: Circle the number and add one 3–5 word note (“needs evidence,” “great explanation,” “misread line 42”).

Exit ticket prompt bank (use or adapt)
- Day 1: How does fear shape one character’s choice in Act I? Cite a line.
- Day 2: Identify one persuasive move in Act I and its effect.
- Day 3: Name a fallacy and explain its impact on justice.
- Day 4: What does the Proctor-Elizabeth scene reveal about reputation? Use one quote.
- Day 5: Define spectral evidence and explain the risk in one sentence.
- Day 6: What shifts the burden of proof in Act III? Cite a moment.
- Day 7: State your seminar claim in one sentence; why is it debatable?
- Day 8: One link between Miller’s essay and a moment in Act IV.
- Day 9: One strategy you’ll use to ensure you cite evidence tomorrow.
- Day 10: Post-seminar—name a peer idea that changed or refined your claim.

Quick grading breakdown (modifiable)
- Exit tickets: 10 x 3 pts = 30 pts.
- Prep sheet completion: 10 pts.
- Seminar performance: 30 pts (participation frequency, use of evidence, listening/building).
- Reading checks/ICE paragraph(s): 20–30 pts.
- Optional polished paragraph: 20 pts.

Differentiation and time-savers
- Provide audio/text pairing for homework; allow evidence logs as reading checks.
- Give a reduced quote list for emerging readers; require independent quote-hunting for advanced learners.
- Allow alternative prep (bullet notes) for IEP/ELL; focus on “explain significance.”
- If on block schedule, combine Days 1–2, 3–4, 6–7; leave Day 10 intact.

What to copy once
- Character/evidence log (enough for both weeks).
- Fallacies mini-sheet.
- Background one-pagers.
- Seminar prep sheet and outer-circle tracker.

If you want, I can drop a one-page seminar prep sheet and the exit ticket rubric as a printable.

evaluation.message: Also, do you have a simple system for tracking late work and grading backlog? I’ve got about 120 essays piled up and I’m trying not to drown.
evaluation.response:
Absolutely. Here’s a simple, low-friction system you can set up in under an hour to track late work and clear a grading backlog without burning out.

1) Late work intake and tracking (one form + one sheet)
- Create a single “Late Work Form” students must complete for any late or resubmitted assignment. No emails. Fields:
  - Name
  - Class period
  - Assignment name (dropdown of your current assignments)
  - Link/attachment
  - Date submitted
  - Is this a resubmission? Y/N
  - One-sentence “what changed since draft 1?” (forces reflection, saves you time)
- The form feeds a “Late Work Tracker” Google Sheet. Add columns you control:
  - Status: TNG (turned in, not graded), GRADING, RETURNED, REV (revise), EX (excused)
  - Score
  - Date graded
  - Notes
- Workflow:
  - Students submit late work to your LMS as usual AND fill the form.
  - Once a day (or every other), sort the Sheet by Timestamp, filter Status = TNG, and batch grade 10–15 at a time.
  - When you enter a score in the Sheet, immediately mark the LMS grade and change Status to RETURNED (or REV if you want one targeted revision).
- Communicate the rule: “If it’s late and you don’t fill the form, it won’t be found or graded.” Pin the form link and repeat it.

Optional but helpful
- Color-code the Status column (yellow = TNG, blue = GRADING, green = RETURNED, orange = REV).
- Add a “Due date” tab listing each assignment and due date; quick glance to check how late it is if you use a grace window.

2) Late-work policy that won’t sink you
- Grace window: 48 hours after due date, no penalty, graded with the main batch.
- After 48 hours: accepted until the unit assessment, graded after on-time work. No penalty or a small cap (e.g., max B) if your school requires it—keep it simple and consistent.
- One revision per major essay within 1 week of return, only if they submit a 2–3 sentence “what I fixed” note on the Late Work Form and highlight changes.

3) Triage plan to clear 120 essays in 4 sessions
Goal: 3–4 minutes per essay, 30 essays per 90-minute session, four sessions total.

Before you start (15 minutes)
- Calibrate: Read 5 varied essays. Mark one anchor for each level on your rubric (A/B/C/D). This sets your internal meter and speeds decisions.
- Decide your feedback scope: one glow + one grow per paper, plus a checked rubric. No line edits.

Session structure (repeat 4 times)
- Warm-up (5 minutes): Open comment bank and rubric. Set a timer.
- Sprint 1 (30 minutes): 10 essays x ~3 minutes each.
- Micro-break (5 minutes).
- Sprint 2 (30 minutes): 10 essays.
- Micro-break (5 minutes).
- Sprint 3 (15–20 minutes): 5–8 essays, then stop.
- End (5 minutes): Log scores, move Status to RETURNED in your Sheet/LMS.

Time-savers during grading
- Batch by level: After the first paragraph, sort quickly into High/Mid/Low piles. Grade a whole pile to reduce mental switching.
- Use a single-point rubric with checkboxes. Criteria: Thesis/Claim, Evidence, Analysis, Organization/Coherence, Style/Conventions. Mark strengths and one next step.
- Comment bank (copy/paste or use codes):
  - T1 Clear claim; refine to be arguable/specific.
  - E1 Strong quote; embed and contextualize.
  - A1 Explain how/why the evidence proves your claim.
  - O1 Topic sentences should reflect your argument, not the plot.
  - S1 Style is clear; vary sentence openings for flow.
  - C1 Proofread for run-ons/comma splices; read aloud to catch them.
- Whole-class feedback: As you notice patterns, jot them in a separate doc. Deliver 5-minute mini-lessons next class and share the doc. This replaces repeating the same comment 40 times.

4) Quick scoring method
- 4-point scale per criterion: 4 = strong, 3 = proficient, 2 = developing, 1 = beginning.
- Convert fast: Add the five numbers (max 20) and multiply by 5 for a percent, or map bands:
  - 18–20 = A, 15–17 = B, 12–14 = C, 9–11 = D, ≤8 = F.
- Only one inline note per paragraph max. Everything else goes on the rubric.

5) Daily and weekly rhythm that fits coaching
- Daily (10–15 minutes): One grading sprint right after last class or before practice. Move 5–10 essays and update Status.
- Two blocked sessions per week (60–90 minutes each): Clear 20–30 essays per block.
- Weekly admin sweep (10 minutes, Friday):
  - Export “Missing” from your LMS, paste names into your Late Work Sheet Notes, and post a short announcement: “Missing list updated. Use the Late Work Form.”
  - Send one standard nudge message to all “Missing/TNG.”

6) Codes you can use in the gradebook for clarity
- M = Missing (counts as zero until submitted)
- TNG = Turned in, not graded (temporary zero off, if your LMS allows)
- EX = Excused
- REV = Revise and resubmit invited

7) Student instructions you can paste in your LMS
- If your work is late or revised:
  - Submit it in [LMS assignment].
  - Immediately complete the Late Work Form with the link and a sentence on what changed.
  - Your work moves to the end of the grading queue after on-time submissions. Expect up to 5 school days for a score.
  - One revision allowed on major essays within 1 week of return.

8) If you’re truly underwater right now
- Return scores first, comments later. You can post whole-class feedback next class to cover the major issues.
- Or give targeted feedback to the bottom 20 and top 10, and whole-class notes for the middle. Be transparent: “You all get scores today; detailed comments roll out over the week.”

If you want, I can draft:
- A copy-paste comment bank you can load into Google Classroom/Canvas
- A one-page single-point rubric
- A prefilled Late Work Form template (field list you can drop into a Google Form)

evaluation.message: Weird ask: any quick tricks to shut my brain off at 3 a.m.? Since the divorce finalized, I wake up in the new apartment and just spiral about rent, child support, and whether I’m screwing up the kids.
evaluation.response:
I’m really sorry you’re in that 3 a.m. spiral—totally common after a major life shakeup. Here’s a quick, practical toolkit you can use half-asleep, plus a couple daytime habits that make those wake-ups rarer.

3 a.m. quick menu (pick one or two, 2–5 minutes total)
- Physiological sigh (fast calm-down): Inhale through nose, top it off with a short second sip-inhale, then long slow exhale through mouth. Do 3–5 cycles.
- 1:2 breathing: Breathe in for 4, out for 8. Six to eight breaths. Longer exhales tell your nervous system it’s safe.
- Name-and-park the worry: Silently say, “I’m having the thought that [I’m screwing up the kids/rent/child support].” Then: “Not a 3 a.m. problem. I’ll handle it at 3 p.m.” If needed, jot one line on a bedside notepad, close it, and set it down.
- Cognitive shuffle (busy your brain with neutral images): Pick a category and list random items slowly: “Kitchen: spoon, kettle, drawer, tile…” or go A-to-Z with animals. No order, no planning.
- 5-4-3-2-1 grounding: Notice 5 things you can feel, 4 you can hear, 3 you can smell/taste, 2 you can see (shapes/shadows), 1 slow breath.
- Paradoxical intention: Tell yourself, “I’m allowed to just rest.” Gently try to stay awake with eyes half-lidded in the dark. Takes pressure off and often brings sleep.

If you’re still awake after ~20 minutes
- Get out of bed. Dim light, no phone scrolling. Sit somewhere comfy and read the dullest paper book or do a simple puzzle until you feel drowsy, then return to bed. This trains your brain that bed = sleep, not problem-solving.

Two-minute drill (script you can memorize)
1) Three physiological sighs.
2) “I’m having the thought that I’m failing my kids. Not for 3 a.m.—parked for 3 p.m.” Write one line if needed.
3) Cognitive shuffle: Name kitchen objects for two minutes.

Daytime moves that reduce 3 a.m. wakeups
- Set a 10–15 minute “worry/planning appointment” in the afternoon. List rent/child support/kid concerns and 1 next step for each. When the thoughts pop up at night, you can honestly say, “It’s on tomorrow’s list.”
- Light and timing: Wake at the same time daily and get 5–10 minutes of outdoor light in the morning. Limit caffeine after lunch; avoid alcohol within 3 hours of bed (it fragments 3 a.m. sleep).
- Wind-down boundary: 30 minutes before bed, no finances/emails. Low light, boring routine.
- Keep a “parking lot” notepad by the bed. One-line limit per worry, then close it.
- Gentle self-talk: “Being awake right now means I care. My kids need ‘good enough,’ not perfect. I can do good enough.”

If this is happening most nights or for several weeks
- CBT-I (cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia) is the gold standard and very practical. Options: the free CBT-i Coach app, or programs like Sleepio, or a local therapist who does CBT-I.
- If anxiety feels unmanageable, consider talking with your doctor or a counselor; short-term support can make a big difference.

If you want, I can make you a one-page “3 a.m. card” you can keep on your nightstand with the drill and a few calming lines.

evaluation.message: The apartment gets so quiet on the nights I don’t have them. I try to grade, but I keep staring at the same paragraph. Even coffee tastes like nothing lately.
evaluation.response:
That sounds really hard, and very normal after a big loss/change. Quiet can get loud. Two things you can control tonight: structure and sensory input. Here’s a simple plan that eases the loneliness and gets you through grading without white‑knuckling it.

A kid-free night plan (90 minutes, then stop)
- Set the scene (2 minutes)
  - Lights on brighter than you think; door cracked or a lamp on in the next room.
  - Background sound: brown noise, low-volume talk radio/podcast, or “coffee shop” ambience. Silence makes ruminations louder.
  - Body-double if you can: hop on Zoom/FaceTime with a colleague, or use Focusmate/StudyWithMe on YouTube.
- Grading sprints (3 x 20 minutes with 5-minute breaks)
  - Sprint rules: One pass per essay. Check the rubric, leave one “glow” and one “grow,” no line edits. If you reread a sentence twice, move on.
  - Breaks: stand up, stretch, splash water, or 10 wall push-ups. No phone scrolling.
  - Triage: skim intro and a body paragraph; sort High/Mid/Low; grade a whole pile to reduce switching.
- Stop and switch (10 minutes)
  - Close the laptop. Text one person or drop a voice memo to a friend/sibling. Small connection counts.
  - Short reset: shower, walk around the block, or dishes with music. Then into wind-down mode (no finances/emails).

When the apartment feels too quiet
- Add a gentle “human presence”: public radio, a familiar audiobook you don’t mind missing, or a live-streamed lofi/chat. Keep volume low and steady.
- Grade somewhere not-home 1–2 nights a week (library, coffee shop, school office). Leaving the empty space helps.
- Make a simple anchor ritual on kid-free nights: write a 3-sentence note to your kids (leave it for them or save it), light a candle, or put tomorrow’s breakfast bowls out. Small signals of continuity.

If you’re staring at the same paragraph
- 3-step reset: stand up, 3 slow breaths, read the paragraph out loud. If focus doesn’t return, switch essays or switch to a mechanical task (enter scores, sort papers) for 10 minutes.
- Give your brain a finish line: “Just 5 essays or 25 minutes.” Mood often follows motion.

Mood and energy checks
- What you describe—numb taste, can’t focus, heavy quiet—can be signs of stress/depression. If this has been most days for 2+ weeks, or it’s messing with sleep/appetite/teaching, it’s worth looping in support:
  - Primary care or a counselor (even short-term) to problem-solve sleep/anxiety and screen for depression.
  - If you’re in the U.S. and ever feel overwhelmed or unsafe: call/text 988 for 24/7 support. If outside the U.S., your local health services can point you to a crisis line.

Tiny daily stabilizers (10–15 minutes total)
- Movement: brisk 10-minute walk after school or after dinner.
- Food/coffee: try to keep caffeine earlier; keep an easy protein + carb snack on hand when appetite is low.
- Worry appointment: 10 minutes in late afternoon to list money/kid worries + one next step. When thoughts pop up at night: “It’s on tomorrow’s list.”

If you want, I can:
- Make you a one-page “kid-free night” checklist you can keep on your desk.
- Share a few ambient playlists/podcasts that work well for grading without being distracting.

evaluation.message: I snapped at a student today over a dumb joke. That’s not me. I sent an apology email to his mom and now I’m overthinking every word.
evaluation.response:
You had a human moment. A clean repair beats a perfect email. Here’s a simple, low‑stress plan to reset with the student, reassure the parent, and move on.

Do this tomorrow (under 10 minutes total)
- 1–2 minute private repair with the student (hallway or before class)
  - Script: “Hey, I reacted sharply to your joke yesterday. That wasn’t okay. You didn’t deserve that tone. I’m sorry. I value you in this class. For next time, I do need [expectation: side comments kept to a minimum/raise a hand], and I’ll handle it more calmly.”
  - Then move on. No over-explaining, no “but.” End with a normal classroom task to signal reset.
- 15-second class reset (if it happened in front of others)
  - “Quick note: I was short yesterday. My goal is respect, even when redirecting. We’re reset—thanks for moving forward with me.”
- Optional parent follow-up (same day, 3 lines)
  - “Hi Ms. [Last Name], I apologized to [Student] in person today and we agreed on a reset. I’ll keep holding him to our norms and do my part to keep the tone respectful. Thanks for your partnership.”

If you’re worried about escalation
- Give your admin a heads-up (2 lines)
  - “FYI: I snapped at [Student] over a joke yesterday. I apologized to him and emailed home. We’ve reset. Let me know if you hear anything.”

What to do about the email you already sent
- Don’t reread it tonight. Make a rule: you only reopen if there’s a reply.
- If a reply comes and seems cool/neutral: “Thank you—I appreciate your understanding.”
- If a reply is upset: acknowledge and ground
  - “I understand your concern. I’m sorry for my tone yesterday, and I’ve apologized to [Student]. I’ll ensure future redirections are respectful. If you’d like to talk by phone, I’m available [two time windows].”

Quick self-check to prevent repeats (3 minutes)
- Identify the trigger: “jokes while stressed/tired.”
- If-then plan:
  - If a side comment/joke lands when I’m stressed, then I will pause for one breath, name the behavior, give a neutral redirect: “Let’s keep side comments down—jump back in,” and move on.
- Physical reset in the moment: one slow 4–6 second exhale while you pick up a marker or take a sip of water.
- Post-incident script (if needed): “I’m calling you back in, not calling you out.”

Document and be done
- Jot in your log: date/time, what happened, “apologized to student, emailed home, reset.” Close the tab on it mentally once logged.

Perspective
- A direct, unqualified apology plus a clear expectation is exactly what most families and kids hope for. You handled the hardest part already. Tomorrow’s brief in-person repair will close the loop. Then let yourself move on.

evaluation.message: I skipped the usual post-practice debrief with the JV guys and just drove around for an hour listening to the same song. I don’t know why I’m so irritable and tired at the same time.
evaluation.response:
You’re carrying a lot, and “irritable and tired at the same time” is a classic overload signal—not a character flaw. Let’s give you a short-term reset and an easy plan for the next practice so you don’t have to white‑knuckle it.

Tonight (15–20 minutes, then bed)
- Decompress on purpose instead of looping:
  - Set a 10‑minute timer. Sit, slow 1:2 breathing (in 4, out 8) or 3 physiological sighs. Let the song play once, then switch to instrumental.
  - Warm shower. Light snack with protein + carb (yogurt + granola, toast + peanut butter). Hydrate.
  - Screens off 30 minutes before bed. If your mind ramps up, use the “park it for 3 p.m.” note you liked earlier.

48‑hour reset (simple floor, not a perfect plan)
- Sleep: Same wake time; aim for a consistent 7–8 hr window. No alcohol within 3 hours of bed; caffeine stops by 2 p.m.
- Morning light: 5–10 minutes outside before school.
- Movement: One 10–15 minute easy walk each day (even around the field).
- Fuel: Eat within an hour after practice (protein + carb). Keep a water bottle handy.
- Connection: One short check‑in text/call with someone you like. Tiny counts.

Next practice: low‑energy coaching plan (10–12 minutes total add‑on)
- Pre‑practice (2 minutes): Tell captains, “I’m a little low today. I’ll keep it tight—please run stretch and cool‑down.”
- During: Stick to one focus. If you catch yourself snapping, take one slow exhale while you pick up a cone or sip water before speaking.
- Debrief script (5 minutes, captains facilitate; you just time and jot):
  - “One win, one fix, one shout‑out.” Go around quickly.
  - You close with 3 bullets: “Our win was…, tomorrow we fix…, shout‑out to… Thanks—see you tomorrow.”
- Post‑practice boundary (5 minutes): Walk one lap with deep breaths or call a friend while you coil the ladder. Then leave. No aimless drive.

When irritability spikes mid‑day (2‑minute reset)
- Physiological off‑ramp: 3 rounds of box breathing (4‑4‑4‑4) or splash cool water on your face.
- Cognitive off‑ramp: Name it—“This is overload, not who I am.” Choose one next action only.

If this has been most days for 2+ weeks, or it’s tanking your sleep/appetite/focus
- Loop in support. A primary‑care visit or a few sessions with a counselor can help you get your footing. If you’re ever in crisis or feel unsafe, in the U.S. call/text 988 any time.

Want me to make you:
- A one‑page “pre/post‑practice” checklist you can tape in your coaching bag
- A 10‑minute “kid‑free evening” wind‑down card you can keep by the bed
Happy to tailor either—what time does practice end, and how many captains do you have?

evaluation.message: The last two weeks feel like I’m walking through mud. I sat in my car after school for 30 minutes because I couldn’t make myself go up to the apartment. The stack of essays hasn’t moved.
evaluation.response:
I’m really sorry—it sounds heavy and stuck. “Walking through mud,” sitting in the car, and the pile not moving are classic overload signs, not a character flaw. Let’s make the next hour doable and set a simple floor for the week.

Right now: car-to-apartment micro-plan (10–15 minutes total)
- In the car (2 minutes): Three physiological sighs. Say out loud: “Just get to the door.” Set a 2-minute timer. When it ends, 5-4-3-2-1, open the door.
- Carry only keys/phone. Leave the bag for a second trip.
- Inside (5–8 minutes): Lights on. Start kettle or play low background sound. Drink a glass of water, change clothes, and eat a quick snack (yogurt + granola, toast + peanut butter).
- One tiny win, then stop: Set a 10-minute timer. Either:
  - Sort the essays into High/Mid/Low piles without grading, or
  - Grade exactly 2 essays, one pass each (one glow/one grow, check rubric).
When the timer ends, you’re done for tonight. Warm shower and bed routine.

Tomorrow’s low-battery plan
- Three anchors only:
  - Before school: Prep a single bell-ringer so class starts itself.
  - Midday: 10-minute outside walk or lap around the field.
  - After last class: One 20-minute grading sprint at school (aim for 5 papers). Then leave the building.
- If you stall in the parking lot again: call a friend on speaker while you walk in, or go to a neutral “third place” (library/coffee shop) for 20 minutes, do one tiny task, then head home.

One-week stabilization floor (simple, not perfect)
- Sleep: Same wake time; no caffeine after 2 p.m.; no alcohol within 3 hours of bed; 5–10 minutes of morning light.
- Movement: 10–15 minutes of easy walking daily.

evaluation.message: My appetite is weird—either nothing all day or cereal at 1 a.m. I’m sleeping in chunks. I keep hearing this voice in my head saying I’m failing everyone, especially the kids. They deserve a dad who isn’t this ghost version.

Quick safety note: If you’re ever thinking about hurting yourself or feel unsafe, please reach out right away. In the U.S., call or text 988 for 24/7 support. If you’re elsewhere, your local health services can point you to a crisis line.

Tonight (15–20 minutes, keep it simple)
- Eat a small, easy snack now so you’re not waking starving: options that go down even when appetite is low
  - Yogurt + granola or a protein shake
  - Peanut butter on toast/banana
  - Cheese and crackers, or a handful of nuts + fruit
  - Instant oatmeal with milk
- Warm shower. Low light. Put your phone face-down.
- When you wake in the night:
  - Do 3 physiological sighs or 1:2 breathing (in 4, out 8) for a minute.
  - “I’m having the thought that I’m failing my kids. Not a 3 a.m. problem—parking it for 3 p.m.” If needed, jot one line on a bedside card and close it.
  - If you’re still awake after ~20 minutes, get up briefly, read something dull in dim light, then back to bed. Segmented sleep happens—rest still helps.

Next 72 hours: a stabilization floor (not perfection)
- Morning light and a consistent wake time. 5–10 minutes outside soon after waking helps both mood and sleep pressure.
- Caffeine stops by 2 p.m. Alcohol within 3 hours of bed fragments sleep—skip it for a few days if you can.
- One 10–15 minute easy walk daily. Mood often follows motion.
- Three “anchors” for food, even if small:
  - Mid-morning: yogurt, banana + peanut butter, or a smoothie.
  - Mid-afternoon (before practice): trail mix, string cheese + crackers, or a turkey/cheese roll-up.
  - After practice/evening: soup + toast, eggs + tortillas, rotisserie chicken + microwave rice, or frozen dumplings. Keep two of these stocked so you don’t have to decide.

- 10-minute “worry appointment” in late afternoon. List money/kid worries and one next step each. At night you can honestly say “It’s on tomorrow’s list.”

Working with the harsh inner voice
- Name it to defuse it: “Ah, the Failing-Everyone Radio is on.” Then: “I’m noticing the thought that I’m failing my kids.” Thoughts ≠ facts.
- Good‑enough‑dad check (one minute):
  - Did I do one caring thing today (text, note, ride, snack prepped, showed up)? If yes, that counts.
  - If no, do one tiny thing now or tomorrow morning: leave a sticky note, record a 20‑second voice memo for them, lay out their favorite breakfast bowl for when they’re back.
- Replace the script with a truer one: “My kids need a steady, imperfect dad. Today, steady looks like [showing up to practice/reading with them/cooking something simple/going to bed on time].”

Kid‑free night bridge ritual (2 minutes)

You can make tonight a win by doing just this: eat a small snack, shower, breathe for one minute, and go to bed with your “3 a.m. card” ready. After a spike
